statement.p: For linear transformation \funcdef{T}{V}{W}, \ker T is a subspace of the domain space V and \im T is a subspace of the codomain space W.

paragraphs.title: Kernel is a subspace
paragraphs.p:
Apply the . Nonempty
By Statement of , \ker T always contains \zerovec_V, the zero vector in the domain space V.
Closed under addition
Suppose \uvec{v}_1,\uvec{v}_2 are in \ker T. Is \uvec{v}_1 + \uvec{v}_2 also in \ker T? Using the additivity of T, we have
T(\uvec{v}_1 + \uvec{v}_2) = T(\uvec{v}_1) + T(\uvec{v}_2) = \zerovec_W + \zerovec_W = \zerovec_W , so yes, \uvec{v}_1 + \uvec{v}_2 is also in \ker T.
Closed under scalar multiplication
Suppose \uvec{v} is in \ker T. Is k \uvec{v} also in \ker T for arbitrary scalar k? Using the homogeneity of T, we have T(k \uvec{v}) = k T(\uvec{v}) = k \zerovec_W = \zerovec_W , so yes, k \uvec{v} is also in \ker T.

paragraphs.title: Image is a subspace
paragraphs.p:
Apply the . Nonempty
By Statement of , \im T always contains \zerovec_W, the zero vector in the codomain space W.
Closed under addition
Suppose \uvec{w}_1,\uvec{w}_2 are in \im T, so that there exist \uvec{v}_1,\uvec{v}_2 in V with
T(\uvec{v}_1) \amp = \uvec{w}_1 \text{,} \amp T(\uvec{v}_2) \amp = \uvec{w}_2 . Is \uvec{w}_1 + \uvec{w}_2 also in \im T? Using the additivity of T, we have
\uvec{w}_1 + \uvec{w}_2 = T(\uvec{v}_1) + T(\uvec{v}_2) = T(\uvec{v}_1 + \uvec{v}_2) , so yes, \uvec{w}_1 + \uvec{w}_2 is also in \im T.
Closed under scalar multiplication
Suppose \uvec{w} is in \im T, so that there exists \uvec{v} in V with T(\uvec{v}) = \uvec{w} . Is k \uvec{w} also in \im T for arbitrary scalar k? Using the homogeneity of T, we have k \uvec{w} = k T(\uvec{v}) = T(k \uvec{v}) , so yes, k \uvec{w} is also in \im T.

subsection.title: Basis and dimension of kernel and image
subsection.p: First we formally state the pattern of , which we discussed further in .

lemma.title: Image of a spanning set is a spanning set for the image

subsection.p: Now we will justify the conclusion of .

statement.p:
Suppose \funcdef{T}{V}{W} is linear with V finite-dimensional, and
\basisfont{K} \amp = \{ \uvec{u}_1, \dotsc, \uvec{u}_m \} \text{,} \amp \basisfont{K}' \amp = \{ \uvec{v}_1, \dotsc, \uvec{v}_\ell \}
are collections of vectors in V so that
\basisfont{K} is a basis for \ker T, and
the vectors of \basisfont{K},\basisfont{K}', taken all together, form a basis for V.
Then the collection of image vectors T(\basisfont{K}') = \{ T(\uvec{v}_1), \dotsc, T(\uvec{v}_\ell) \} is a basis for \im T.

proof.p: We need to establish that the collection T(\basisfont{K}') is both linearly independent and a spanning set for \im T.

case.title: Linear independence
case.p:
To apply the , we begin with a homogeneous vector equation k_1 T(\uvec{v}_1) + k_2 T(\uvec{v}_2) + \dotsb + k_\ell T(\uvec{v}_\ell) = \zerovec_W . The linearity of T can be used to collapse the linear combination on the left into a single image vector T(k_1 \uvec{v}_1 + k_2 \uvec{v}_2 + \dotsb + k_\ell \uvec{v}_\ell) = \zerovec_W , which implies that the domain space linear combination k_1 \uvec{v}_1 + k_2 \uvec{v}_2 + \dotsb + k_\ell \uvec{v}_\ell is in \ker T. Since the vectors in \basisfont{K} are a basis for \ker T, there exist scalars a_1,a_2,\dotsc,a_m so that
k_1 \uvec{v}_1 + k_2 \uvec{v}_2 + \dotsb + k_\ell \uvec{v}_\ell = a_1 \uvec{u}_1 + a_2 \uvec{u}_2 + \dotsb + a_m \uvec{u}_m . Rearranging, we obtain
k_1 \uvec{v}_1 + k_2 \uvec{v}_2 + \dotsb + k_\ell \uvec{v}_\ell - a_1 \uvec{u}_1 - a_2 \uvec{u}_2 - \dotsb - a_m \uvec{u}_m = \zerovec_V . On the left is now a linear combination of all the vectors from \basisfont{K} and \basisfont{K}'. But we have assumed that these vectors together form a basis for V, hence are linearly independent. So the only way this last vector equation above is possible is the trivial way:
k_1 = k_2 = \dotsb = k_\ell \amp = 0 \text{,} \amp a_1 = a_2 = \dotsb = a_m \amp = 0 . In particular, since all of the k_j scalars must be zero, we can conclude that the vectors in T(\basisfont{K}') are independent, as desired.

case.title: Spans
case.p:
Write \basisfont{B}_V for the collection of all vectors from \basisfont{K} and \basisfont{K}' taken together, which we have assumed is a basis for the domain space V. By , the collection of image vectors
T(\basisfont{B}_V) = \{ T(\uvec{u}_1), \dotsc, T(\uvec{u}_m), T(\uvec{v}_1), \dotsc, T(\uvec{v}_\ell) \}
is a spanning set for \im T. But since the \uvec{u}_j are in \ker T, we actually have
T(\basisfont{B}_V) = \{ \zerovec_W, \dotsc, \zerovec_W, T(\uvec{v}_1), \dotsc, T(\uvec{v}_\ell) \} , and clearly the collection of image vectors T(\basisfont{K}') = \{ T(\uvec{v}_1), \dotsc, T(\uvec{v}_\ell) \} will span the same space that T(\basisfont{B}_V) does.

subsection.p: Finally, we can connect the dimensions of the kernel and image of a transformation.

statement.p: Suppose \funcdef{T}{V}{W} is linear with V finite-dimensional. Then the sum of the rank and nullity of T is the dimension of the domain space V. That is, \dim (\ker T) + \dim (\im T) = \dim V .

proof.p: Let \basisfont{K} be a basis for \ker T, and let \basisfont{K}' be a collection of vectors in V that enlarges \basisfont{K} to a basis \basisfont{B}_V of V (). Then says that the collection of image vectors T(\basisfont{K}') is a basis for \im T. Now, the collection T(\basisfont{K}') cannot contain any duplicates because it is linearly independent. So T(\basisfont{K}') contains exactly the same number of vectors as \basisfont{K}'.

Using the notation \# S to mean the number of vectors in collection S, we now have
\dim (\ker T) = \# \basisfont{K} \text{,} \dim (\im T) = \# T(\basisfont{K}') = \# \basisfont{K}' \text{,} \dim V = \# \basisfont{K} + \# \basisfont{K}' , and the result follows.
